channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Ukraine Steps Up Evacuation Calls as Russia Attacks in Northeast
item.description: Only 1,400 people out of 11,000 have left the Kupiansk area since regional authorities issued evacuation orders this month, Ukrainian officials say.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Under Uganda Anti-LGBTQ Law, Man Is Arrested on Charge Punishable by Death
item.description: Prosecutors used the death penalty provision of a newly passed law to charge a 20-year-old man. The measure has sown widespread fear among gay Ugandans.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Ugandan Parliament in May during the passage of a bill imposing severe penalties for same-sex sexual acts. It drew condemnation from human rights groups and the United Nations.

item.title: Pressure Mounts on Rubiales Over Unwanted Kiss at World Cup
item.description: Luis Rubiales has defied calls to resign, now echoed by his own federation. Soccer’s world governing body has suspended him, and prosecutors have opened an investigation.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales, Spain’s top soccer official, with members of the country’s World Cup team in Madrid last week.

item.title: In Israel’s Arab Communities, Gun Violence Surges
item.description: At least 155 Arab citizens have died this year in violence largely attributed to organized crime. Some say the government has not done enough to stop the killing.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nabil Hayek, 19, was one of four people injured in a shooting at a butcher’s shop in an Arab town in northern Israel in late July. He once had a promising future on the soccer field.

item.title: China’s Economic Outlook: Pep Talks Up Top, Gloom on the Ground
item.description: Beijing has characterized concerns about the economic slowdown as being inflated by Western critics. Widespread anxiety and pessimism paint a different picture.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: China halved the tax on stock transactions in an attempt to increase investor confidence. But many people are unwilling to buy stocks in the first place, an expert said.

item.title: Scottish Museum Will Return Totem Pole to Nisga’a Nation in Canada
item.description: The 36-foot tall memorial pole has spent almost a century in a Scottish museum. Now it will be returned to the Nisga’a Nation in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Andrew Milligan/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Earl Stephens, who goes by the Nisga’a cultural name Chief Ni’is Joohl, center left, and members of a delegation from the Nisga’a nation pose beside a 36-foot tall memorial pole during a visit to the National Museum of Scotland on Monday.

item.title: Imran Khan’s 3-Year Sentence Is Suspended by Pakistan Appeals Court
item.description: Mr. Khan, who was ousted as prime minister last year, still faces dozens of court cases that could keep him behind bars.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan was sentenced to three years in prison in a corruption case earlier this month.

item.title: U.K. Flights to Be Disrupted for Days After Air Traffic Control Glitch
item.description: The government ruled out a cyberattack as the cause of the technical problems, which forced airlines to cancel about 5 percent of the flights in and out of the country on Tuesday as they tried to catch up.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: People waiting near check-in desks on Monday at Gatwick Airport, south of London.

item.title: A Merchant Ship’s Perilous Black Sea Passage in Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine’s Danube River ports have become key arteries for grain exports. But threats from Russia and costly delays have made some shippers rethink their operations in the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Valerie Hopkins

item.title: To Escape the Heat in Dubai, Head to the Beach at Midnight
item.description: In a city where weather that would constitute a deadly heat wave in Europe is just a typical summer day, official “night beaches” have become a popular way to cool down.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Andrea DiCenzo
item.media:description: Floodlights illuminating Umm Suqeim beach in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, this month.

item.title: Spain’s Soccer Federation Forces Reckoning With Sexism
item.description: The nonconsensual kiss that Luis Rubiales, the president of Spain’s soccer federation, pressed on Jennifer Hermoso has come to embody the generational fault line between a culture of machismo and more recent progressivism.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: Jennifer Hermoso, with teammates Alexia Putellas and Irene Paredes, celebrating Spain’s win in the Women’s World Cup final in Sydney this month.

item.title: A Former French President Gives a Voice to Obstinate Russian Sympathies
item.description: Remarks by Nicolas Sarkozy have raised fears that Europe’s pro-Putin chorus may grow louder as Ukraine’s plodding counteroffensive puts pressure on Western resolve.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France arriving for a meeting on the Russian attack of Ukraine in Paris in February 2022.

item.title: Luis Rubiales and Spain’s World Cup Kissing Scandal: What to Know
item.description: An unwanted kiss cast a pall over the Spanish team’s victory at the Women’s World Cup. Some are calling it a #MeToo moment for the country and for soccer there.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales, the president of Spain’s national soccer federation, carrying Athenea del Castillo, a forward, on his shoulder after the team’s World Cup final victory in Australia this month.

item.title: The Online Scam Industry Is Thriving. Cambodia Plays a Key Role.
item.description: Gangs in Cambodia have compelled thousands of captives to defraud unsuspecting victims. Because of political connections, no one is stopping them.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Barbed-wire fences outside a compound in the coastal city of Sihanoukville, Cambodia, where authorities said they had recovered evidence of human trafficking, kidnapping and torture during raids last year.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Two lines of attack.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers of the 22nd Mechanized Brigade firing a self-propelled howitzer in the Bakhmut region on Monday.

item.title: Macron Tries Outreach to Head Off Further Protests
item.description: After a tumultuous year, the French president is meeting with his opponents in hopes of building bridges. But few seem interested in working with him.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France has been seen as a top-down leader who rarely talks of compromise

item.title: Salmon Die in Droves as Climate Change Burns Canada
item.description: The effects of a summer of environmental catastrophes were felt everywhere in Canada, from its vast boreal forests to a river on Vancouver Island once fished by Hollywood royalty.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Cowichan River, on Canada’s Vancouver Island, saw hundreds of young salmon and trout die last month. The river, a renowned fly-fishing destination, is suffering from the effects of climate change, including a low water level and high water temperatures.

item.title: For Greek Fires and Other Crises, E.U. Builds Emergency Force
item.description: The European Union deployed firefighters and equipment in what could be a preview of how it handles disasters linked to climate change.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Residents watching the fires in the Evros region of northeastern Greece last week. The country is at the frontier of Europe’s climate crisis, which unleashed intense heat waves and wildfires this summer.

item.title: Parisians Want to Bring Their Neighbors Closer Together. But First, Cheese.
item.description: A grass-roots movement aims to recast urban living in Paris and other cities around the world through a hyperlocal prism of neighborliness.
item.dc:creator: Peter Yeung
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrick Bernard, the founder of The Republic of Super Neighbors in Paris, center background, with participants in the 14th arrondissement. He encourages neighbors who interact five times daily to do so 50 times a day,

item.title: Will a Bitterly Divided Australia Elevate the Aboriginal Voice?
item.description: A referendum to set up an Indigenous advisory body in Parliament was envisioned as uniting the country. The opposite has happened.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Garma Festival, the largest Aboriginal cultural gathering in Australia, in East Arnhem Land this month.

item.title: With Multiple Battles, Russia and Ukraine Puzzle Over Where to Put Troops
item.description: Russians are advancing in the Northeast, toward Kupiansk, while Ukraine presses its offensive in the South, each hoping to force the other to redeploy its forces.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers of the 22nd Mechanized Brigade firing a self-propelled howitzer in the Bakhmut region on Monday.

item.title: Rumors and Misdirection Keep Crowds Away From Prigozhin Burial
item.description: The burial of the Wagner mercenary group boss, two months after his mutiny, was shrouded in misinformation, preventing a public display of support the Kremlin did not want to see.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police and National Guard troops surrounded the Porokhovskoye cemetery in St. Petersburg, Russia, where the mercenary boss Yevgeny V. Prigozhin was buried on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: U.S. Businesses Say China Is ‘Uninvestable’
item.description: Also, a legal victory for Imran Khan.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lyna Bentahar
item.media:description: Gina Raimondo’s visit is part of an effort by the Biden administration to stop a long deterioration in the U.S. relationship with China and restore communications.

item.title: Biden Discusses Migration With the President of Costa Rica
item.description: The Biden administration is working with Central American nations like Costa Rica to develop ways for migrants to apply for protection closer to their home countries.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden hosted President Rodrigo Chaves of Costa Rica at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Factories May Be Leaving China, but Trade Ties Are Stronger Than They Seem
item.description: The United States is trying to lessen its dependence on Chinese goods, but research is showing how tough it is to truly alter global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: The United States has decreased its import of goods directly from China, but they are being funneled in through other routes.

item.title: Vatican Tries to Clarify Pope Francis’ Remarks on Russia
item.description: The Holy See sought to calm an outcry over comments that some critics said were too close to President Vladimir Putin’s justifications for invading Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving at his weekly general audience at the Vatican last week.

item.title: Putin Will Not Attend the Funeral for Yevgeny Prigozhin, the Wagner Chief
item.description: Details about the funeral for Yevgeny Prigozhin, who died in a plane crash last week along with nine other people, were murky.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police presence was heavy on Tuesday at the Porokhovskoye cemetery in St. Petersburg, Russia, where the press service of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin said he had been buried.

item.title: U.S. Does Not Want to ‘Decouple’ From China, Raimondo Says
item.description: Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, emphasized U.S. concerns over harsh treatment of foreign companies and national security issues in a meeting with top officials in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: The U.S. commerce secretary, Gina Raimondo, with Vice Premier He Lifeng at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s trial date.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump in Atlanta last week.

item.title: TikTok’s U.S. Future Still in Limbo as Raimondo Visits China
item.description: Gina Raimondo, who is in China this week, has said banning TikTok could “lose every voter under 35, forever.”
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari and David McCabe
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: TikTok creators gathered for a news conference about the app on Capitol Hill in March. Efforts to ban or regulate it in Washington have not yet borne fruit.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Retook Robotyne Village From Russians
item.description: It took weeks of fierce combat for Ukrainian forces to seize the village of Robotyne from the Russians, and they have advanced just a few miles since June — signs of the daunting task ahead.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A destroyed Ukrainian tank near the village of Robotyne, in the Zaporizhzhia region of Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Paul Whelan, American Imprisoned in Russia, Is Seen in a New Video
item.description: In footage posted by the state-owned network RT, he is shown in several settings, including in a cafeteria. Mr. Whelan has been largely out of sight since he was convicted by a Russian court in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Paul Whelan during his espionage trial at the Moscow City Court in June 2020.

item.title: Pope Francis’ Praise for ‘Great Russia’ Empire Draws Criticism
item.description: “Never forget the legacy,” Francis said in a video speech on Friday to young Catholics in St. Petersburg. “You are the heirs of Great Russia: Great Russia of saints, rulers, Great Russia of Peter I, Catherine II, that empire.”
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Sunday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. and China Agree to Broaden Talks
item.description: Also, Cambodia’s cyber-scam industry.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lyna Bentahar
item.media:description: The U.S. commerce secretary, Gina Raimondo, right is meeting with her Chinese counterparts in Beijing and Shanghai this week.

item.title: France to Ban Full-Length Muslim Robes in Public Schools
item.description: Religious symbols are already banned in French schools, but the abaya — a loosefitting robe worn by some Muslim women — was in a gray area. Critics called the measure discriminatory.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: School administration unions said headmasters needed clear instructions on how to deal with a small but growing number of students wearing the abaya, a full-length robe, in class.

item.title: Poland Demands That Belarus Expel Russia’s Wagner Fighters
item.description: Officials from Poland, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia says the presence of the paramilitary force in Belarus following a short-lived rebellion in Russia poses a threat.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A military base near Asipovichy, Belarus, following a tour last month.

item.title: Spanish Prosecutors Open Inquiry Into Luis Rubiales Over World Cup Kiss
item.description: Luis Rubiales caused outrage for kissing a player after Spain won the Women’s World Cup. On Monday, a criminal investigation was begun, and he was told to step down.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler and Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales, Spain’s top soccer official, in Doha, Qatar, in December. As outrage grew over his actions, the country’s soccer federation was under pressure to take action.

item.title: U.S. and China Agree to Broaden Talks in Bid to Ease Tensions
item.description: During a visit to Beijing, Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, said the two sides would meet to discuss export restrictions and intellectual property, among other issues.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: The U.S. commerce secretary, Gina Raimondo, right, is meeting with her Chinese counterparts in Beijing and Shanghai this week.

item.title: Hundreds of Flights Canceled After ‘Technical Issue’ With U.K. Air Traffic Control
item.description: Britain’s air traffic control agency experienced a system fault that lasted several hours, leading to widespread disruption and delays.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Heathrow Airport, near London, in May. “No improvements for flights entering U.K. airspace are foreseen in the near future,” Europe’s air control agency said on Monday.

item.title: Russia Charges Former U.S. Consulate Worker With Collecting War Information
item.description: Robert Shonov, a Russian national, faces up to eight years in prison. The U.S. said the allegations against him are “wholly without merit.”
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: An entrance to Lefortovo Prison in Moscow. Tass, the Russian state news agency, said in May that a former U.S. Embassy employee, Robert Shonov, was being held there.

item.title: Foreign Minister Flees Libya Amid Uproar Over Israeli Meeting
item.description: The minister, Najla el-Mangoush, flew to Turkey after reports emerged that she had met with her Israeli counterpart, sparking unrest in several Libyan cities.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Najla el-Mangoush, Libya’s foreign minister. The prime minister of Libya’s internationally recognized government said he was temporarily suspending her.

item.title: What Would More Sanctions on Russian Diamonds Really Do?
item.description: The Group of 7 and the European Union are expected to issue new rules in an effort to slow the flow of revenue into the Kremlin’s war chest.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Paton
item.media:credit: Maxim Babenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Diamond sorting in Mirny, Russia. Russia is known for producing small diamonds that are mostly sold in very large quantities.

item.title: How to Track a Songbird from Alaska to Peru
item.description: To follow an olive-sided flycatcher, first you have to catch it.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Tools Born From Fracking Fuel Geothermal Rush
item.description: The United States has enough geothermal energy to power the entire country. Some are trying to unlock it by using techniques from the fracking boom.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: A drilling rig used by Fervo Energy outside Milford, Utah. The geothermal start-up aims to extract heat from underground granite to produce electricity.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: The future of the Wagner private military company.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in Moscow for Yevgeny Prigozhin.

item.title: A 12,000-Year-Old Bird Call, Made of Bird Bones
item.description: A collection of small flutes carved from waterfowl bones may have been used as hunting aids, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz

item.title: Haiti Gang Shoots at Protesters, Killing Several in Port-au-Prince
item.description: The shooting reflects escalating tensions as vigilante groups push back against gangs in areas around Port-au-Prince.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Andre Paultre
item.media:description: Relatives of people who were killed during a religious march in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Russia Confirmed Prigozhin’s Death
item.description: Also, three U.S. Marines died in an air crash in Australia.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yevgeny Prigozhin led the Wagner private military group, which has operated in Syria, Africa and Ukraine.

item.title: Hailstorm in Germany Rips Through a Town, Damaging Buildings and Cars
item.description: An estimated 80 percent of buildings were damaged during a hailstorm in Bad Bayersoien, Germany.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Remains of a marquee destroyed by a storm on the outskirts of Kissing, Germany, on Saturday.

item.title: With Prigozhin Dead, Russia’s Wagner Faces an Uncertain Future
item.description: It could be hard for the Kremlin to find a way to neutralize the mercenary group after Yevgeny Prigozhin’s death while retaining its fighting power and geopolitical links.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Moscow paid their respects this weekend at a makeshift memorial for Yevgeny Prigozhin, head of the Wagner mercenary group, and others killed last week.

item.title: Zimbabwe’s Neighbors Cast Doubt on Elections That Gave Mnangagwa the Win
item.description: The main regional bloc in southern Africa and the African Union declined to rubber stamp the elections and cast doubt on a vote that led to President Emmerson Mnangagwa’s re-election.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Tendai Marima
item.category: Citizens Coalition for Change (Zimbabwean Political Party)
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Campaign posters for President Emmerson Mnangagwa of Zimbabwe in Harare, the capital, on Sunday.

item.title: After Prigozhin’s Death, Mourners Gather at Wagner Memorial in Moscow
item.description: Visitors, some tearful, left flowers and other tributes to Yevgeny Prigozhin, the founder of the Wagner private military company, at a sidewalk memorial.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sidewalk memorial near Red Square in Moscow has drawn hundreds of mourners since the death of the founder of the Wagner mercenary group, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, and nine others in a plane crash on Wednesday.

item.title: Months After Earthquake, Syrians Feel Forgotten
item.description: In northwestern Syria, a devastating quake six months ago compounded the damage of years of civil war. U.S. lawmakers just visited for the first time in a decade.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Spanish Soccer Chief Finds His Defenders Backing Away
item.description: Luis Rubiales was widely condemned for kissing a player after the Spanish women’s team won the World Cup, but retained a few public supporters. Many now appear to be reconsidering.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: The president of the Spanish soccer federation, Luis Rubiales, right, embracing Rocio Galvez, a player on the national team. He kissed Jennifer Hermoso, left, on the lips.

item.title: U.S. Commerce Secretary Faces a Wide Range of Issues in China
item.description: From tourism to advanced technology, here are the topics that are dominating the secretary’s visit to China this week.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina Raimondo, U.S. secretary of commerce, center, will meet with Chinese officials during a trip to Beijing and Shanghai.

item.title: Canada Revisits Ancient Prevention Tactics to Battle Wildfires
item.description: A movement to fight wildfires by making forests more resilient and, in some cases, deliberately setting blazes is gaining ground in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A slice of forest in British Columbia that was scorched by fire in 2021. A nearby section of forest was relatively unscathed after Indigenous fire prevention practices were applied there.

item.title: The Joys of Sketching Birds
item.description: Times readers were invited to share their drawings of the avian life around them. Here are more of our favorites.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Western Banks Help Fund Blacklisted Oligarch’s Charity
item.description: Konstantin Malofeyev’s foundation funds orphanages in occupied Ukraine. He denies that a child-removal program there is a war crime: “All of this is fake.”
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Konstantin Malofeyev at the International Russophile Movement congress in Moscow in March.

item.title: Russia Says Ukraine Fired Drones at Three Regions
item.description: The frequency of drone attacks inside Russia has increased in recent weeks, bringing the war to areas deep inside Russian territory.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Soldiers with the 110th Separate Mechanized Brigade firing a self-propelled artillery gun at a Russian target in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. Marines Killed in Air Crash in Australia
item.description: An Osprey aircraft with 23 people on board crashed during a joint training exercise near Darwin, in the north of Australia. Several others were seriously injured.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Damien Cave
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Darren England/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A U.S. Marine MV-22B Osprey off the coast of Brisbane, Australia, in June. This was the type of aircraft that crashed on Sunday.

item.title: Thailand’s Marijuana Business Is Growing Despite Regulatory Risks
item.description: The country’s legal marijuana business — a rarity in Asia — is struggling with oversupply, illegal imports and regulatory ambiguity. Investors are piling in anyway.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: A cannabis farm in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand. The latest regulations for marijuana could give an edge to a high-quality domestic supply of weed.
